title: What happens if you guess? - Leigh Nataro

multiple-choice.question: What is the area of mathematics that deals with making predictions and calculating probabilities?

options.label: A
options.text: Statistics

options.label: B
options.text: Probability

options.label: C
options.text: Data Analysis

options.label: D
options.text: Algebra

multiple-choice.question: A weather forecast states there's an 80% chance of snow tomorrow. What type of mathematics is being used to make this prediction?

options.label: A
options.text: Statistics

options.label: B
options.text: Probability

options.label: C
options.text: Data Analysis

options.label: D
options.text: Algebra

multiple-choice.question: If you were to toss a fair coin 10 times and use it to choose the answers on a true/false quiz, what is the probability you would get a perfect score by randomly guessing?

According to the fundamental counting principle, if there are A possible outcomes for one event and B possible outcomes for another event, then there are A times B ways to pair the outcomes. What is the fundamental counting principle?

options.label: A
options.text: If there are A possible outcomes for one event and B possible outcomes for another event, then there are A times B ways to pair the outcomes.

options.label: B
options.text: If there are A possible outcomes for one event and B possible outcomes for another event, then there are A minus B ways to pair the outcomes.

options.label: C
options.text: If there are A possible outcomes for one event and B possible outcomes for another event, then there are A plus B ways to pair the outcomes.

options.label: D
options.text: If there are A possible outcomes for one event and B possible outcomes for another event, then there are A divided by B ways to pair the outcomes.

multiple-choice.question: How many possible ways can you write down different combinations of Ts and Fs on a 10-question true/false quiz?
If you and all your friends were to always randomly guess at every question on a 10-question true/false quiz, what would be the most common score?
If there are 20 questions and five possible answers for each question, what is the probability you would get all 20 right by randomly guessing?

options.label: D
options.text: 1 in 95 trillion

multiple-choice.question: What is the average number of questions you would get right by guessing on a 10-question true/false quiz?
According to the transcript, what is the probability of getting all questions correct by randomly guessing on a 20-question true/false quiz?

options.label: D
options.text: 1 in 95 trillion

multiple-choice.question: Why does it clearly not pay to guess on a true/false quiz?

options.label: A
options.text: Because the probability of getting a question right by guessing is always 1/2.

options.label: B
options.text: Because the probability of getting a question right by guessing is always 1/5.

options.label: C
options.text: Because the probability of getting a question right by guessing is always 1/10.

options.label: D
options.text: Because the probability of getting a question right by guessing is always very small.

multiple-choice.question: What is the main idea that authentic narrative provides in journalism?

options.label: A
options.text: A compelling reason to keep reading

options.label: B
options.text: A universal understanding of a topic

options.label: C
options.text: A humanistic connection to others

options.label: D
options.text: A straightforward presentation of facts

multiple-choice.question: What are the three components of the trifecta of sourcing in journalism?

options.label: A
options.text: Official sources, overview sources, and unofficial sources

options.label: B
options.text: Spokespeople, authors, and consultants

options.label: C
options.text: Academics, stakeholders, and experts

options.label: D
options.text: Journalists, editors, and readers

multiple-choice.question: What do official sources typically provide in a story?

options.label: A
options.text: The why behind an event

options.label: B
options.text: The numbers and answers to how much, how many, where, when, and who

options.label: C
options.text: The big picture view

options.label: D
options.text: The personal insight

multiple-choice.question: How do you identify what is compelling from what is chatter in a story?

options.label: A
options.text: By asking surprising questions

options.label: B
options.text: By presenting bulleted facts and updates

options.label: C
options.text: By using a slow dance of information

options.label: D
options.text: By focusing on exposition and facts

multiple-choice.question: What is the role of unofficial sources in a story?

options.label: A
options.text: To provide the numbers and answers

options.label: B
options.text: To give consequence to an event

options.label: C
options.text: To provide a big picture view

options.label: D
options.text: To offer a humanistic connection

multiple-choice.question: What is the purpose of an anecdote in a story?

options.label: A
options.text: To provide a straightforward presentation of facts

options.label: B
options.text: To convey information quickly

options.label: C
options.text: To breathe life into a grey story

options.label: D
options.text: To offer a big picture view

multiple-choice.question: How do you achieve a complicated, fragile human connection in a story?

options.label: A
options.text: By asking surprising questions

options.label: B
options.text: By presenting bulleted facts and updates

options.label: C
options.text: By focusing on exposition and facts

options.label: D
options.text: By using a slow dance of information

multiple-choice.question: What is the main difference between a narrative personal story and a straightforward presentation of facts?

options.label: A
options.text: The use of anecdotes

options.label: B
options.text: The presentation of bulleted facts and updates

options.label: C
options.text: The luxury of a slow dance of information

options.label: D
options.text: The focus on exposition and facts

multiple-choice.question: Why is it important to regard the stories of every subject as sacred in journalism?

options.label: A
options.text: To provide a humanistic connection

options.label: B
options.text: To achieve a complicated, fragile human connection

options.label: C
options.text: To breathe life into a grey story

options.label: D
options.text: To convey information quickly

multiple-choice.question: What is the artful solicitation of story in journalism?

options.label: A
options.text: The presentation of bulleted facts and updates

options.label: B
options.text: The use of anecdotes

options.label: C
options.text: The slow dance of information

options.label: D
options.text: The art of asking surprising questions

title: How fiction can change reality - Jessica Wise

multiple-choice.question: Who said, "There is no frigate like a book to take us lands away..."

options.label: A
options.text: Emily Dickinson

options.label: B
options.text: Jane Austen

options.label: C
options.text: Mark Twain

options.label: D
options.text: Samuel Richardson

multiple-choice.question: According to the transcript, what do researchers in psychology, neuroscience, child development, and biology have discovered about stories?

options.label: A
options.text: That stories are not effective in changing a person's point of view.

options.label: B
options.text: That stories have a unique ability to change a person's point of view.

options.label: C
options.text: That stories are only effective in fiction, not in real life.

options.label: D
options.text: That stories are not important in shaping culture.

multiple-choice.question: What was the impact of Samuel Richardson's novel "Pamela" on society?

options.label: A
options.text: It caused no significant change or debate.

options.label: B
options.text: It was ignored by the public and press.

options.label: C
options.text: It spawned intense debate and several counter-novels.

options.label: D
options.text: It was a bestseller but had no lasting impact.

multiple-choice.question: What is an example of a novel that challenged traditional ideas of marriage and class.

options.label: A
options.text: "Pride and Prejudice"

options.label: B
options.text: "Jane Eyre"

options.label: C
options.text: "Pamela"

options.label: D
options.text: "Twilight"

multiple-choice.question: According to the transcript, what is one of the characteristics that Darwin's theory of evolution privileges?

options.label: A
options.text: Intelligence, swiftness, and adaptability to change

options.label: B
options.text: Strength, speed, and physical appearance

options.label: C
options.text: Intelligence, physical strength, and beauty

options.label: D
options.text: Creativity, kindness, and wisdom

multiple-choice.question: What recent study suggests might be wrong about our sense of being a hero?

options.label: A
options.text: That we are hardwired for competition and being solitary heroes.

options.label: B
options.text: That we are not capable of being heroes at all.

options.label: C
options.text: That being a hero is only for men.

options.label: D
options.text: That being a hero is only for women.

multiple-choice.question: Why should we still read and enjoy classic novels?

options.label: A
options.text: Because they are outdated and no longer relevant.

options.label: B
options.text: Because they can help us understand the terrain has changed.

options.label: C
options.text: Because they can teach us what to expect from ourselves.

options.label: D
options.text: Because they are not worth reading anymore.

multiple-choice.question: What can "Hunger Games" teach us about capitalism?

options.label: A
options.text: That it is the best system of government.

options.label: B
options.text: That it is the worst system of government.

options.label: C
options.text: That it can lead to a loss of individual freedom.

options.label: D
options.text: That it can lead to a loss of group identity.

multiple-choice.question: What is one of the dangers of pursuing a perfect body, as depicted in "Uglies"?

options.label: A
options.text: That it can lead to a loss of individuality.

options.label: B
options.text: That it can lead to a loss of self-esteem.

options.label: C
options.text: That it can lead to a loss of group identity.

options.label: D
options.text: That it can lead to a loss of freedom.

multiple-choice.question: What is one of the new stories that might engage our imagination in the future?

options.label: A
options.text: "Seekers" and its portrayal of global warming.

options.label: B
options.text: "Uglies" and its portrayal of the dangers of pursuing a perfect body.

options.label: C
options.text: "Hunger Games" and its portrayal of the dangers of capitalism.

options.label: D
options.text: "Seekers", "Uglies", and "Hunger Games" and their portrayal of various social issues.

multiple-choice.question: What is the main reason for dealing with small or large numbers in the context of the transcript?

options.label: A
options.text: To understand the concept of logarithms

options.label: B
options.text: To calculate the pH of water samples

options.label: C
options.text: To find the value of a logarithm

options.label: D
options.text: To understand the concept of exponents

multiple-choice.question: What is the equation that represents an exponential relationship between a base number, b, and a power, p, resulting in a number n?

options.label: A
options.text: b raised to the p power, equals n

options.label: B
options.text: n raised to the b power, equals p

options.label: C
options.text: p raised to the b power, equals n

options.label: D
options.text: b raised to the n power, equals p

multiple-choice.question: What is the value of log base 10 of 10,000?
Why is it important to study logarithms, even if a calculator can compute them?

options.label: A
options.text: To understand the concept of exponents

options.label: B
options.text: To calculate the pH of water samples

options.label: C
options.text: To understand the relationship between logarithms and exponents

options.label: D
options.text: To apply logarithms in real-world scenarios

multiple-choice.question: How can logarithms be used to find the pH of water samples?

options.label: A
options.text: By calculating the negative log base 10 of the hydrogen ion concentration

options.label: B
options.text: By calculating the log base 10 of the hydrogen ion concentration

options.label: C
options.text: By calculating the pH of a sample with a known hydrogen ion concentration

options.label: D
options.text: By using a pH meter

multiple-choice.question: What happens to your eyes when they are exposed to a pH of 8.4?

options.label: A
options.text: They feel nice and comfortable

options.label: B
options.text: They feel itchy and red

options.label: C
options.text: They do not feel any sensation

options.label: D
options.text: They become dry

multiple-choice.question: How can logarithms be used in real-world scenarios, such as in chemistry to find the pH of water samples?

options.label: A
options.text: By calculating the negative log base 10 of the hydrogen ion concentration

options.label: B
options.text: By calculating the log base 10 of the hydrogen ion concentration

options.label: C
options.text: By using a pH meter

options.label: D
options.text: By using a calculator

multiple-choice.question: What is the relationship between logarithms and exponents?

options.label: A
options.text: Logarithms are the inverse of exponents

options.label: B
options.text: Logarithms are a type of exponent

options.label: C
options.text: Logarithms and exponents are related through the equation b raised to the p power, equals n

options.label: D
options.text: Logarithms and exponents are unrelated

multiple-choice.question: How can logarithms be used to solve the equation 2 raised to what power is 64?

options.label: A
options.text: By calculating the log base 2 of 64

options.label: B
options.text: By calculating the log base 10 of 64

options.label: C
options.text: By using a calculator to find the exponent

options.label: D
options.text: By using a logarithmic table

multiple-choice.question: What is the main idea of the transcript, and how do logarithms relate to it?

options.label: A
options.text: The main idea is to understand the concept of logarithms, and logarithms are used to find the pH of water samples

options.label: B
options.text: The main idea is to understand the concept of exponents, and logarithms are a type of exponent

options.label: C
options.text: The main idea is to understand the relationship between logarithms and exponents, and logarithms are used to find the pH of water samples

options.label: D
options.text: The main idea is to understand the concept of logarithms, and logarithms are used to solve equations

title: The history of keeping time - Karen Mensing

options.label: C
options.text: Hourglass

options.label: D
options.text: Atomic clock

options.label: D

options.label: D

options.label: B
